An **ochre jelly**, j, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is an [acidic](/wiki/Acidic "Acidic") [amoeboid](/wiki/Amoeboid "Amoeboid"), and is the only non-[sessile](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile") member of the [jelly](/wiki/Jelly "Jelly") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class").

Like other jellies the ochre jelly has a passive attack, which deals acid damage and can [corrode](/wiki/Corrode "Corrode") [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") or [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") weapons and armor. It can also actively [engulf](/wiki/Engulf "Engulf") a target to cover them with acidic slime.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Ochre jellies are the second quest monster encountered on the [Knight quest](/wiki/Knight_quest "Knight quest") branch, and have a 14% chance of being generated. Several ochre jellies are generated on the floors beyond the home level.

Ochre jellies may also be created by a hostile [spellcaster](/wiki/Spellcaster "Spellcaster") casting the [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

## Strategy

Ochre jellies are quite slow and can be easily outrun, allowing you to pick them off at a distance with corrode-proofed or disposable projectiles - you can also simply run away if you aren't prepared to handle them. Their passive acid attack does 3d6 damage as opposed to the (XL + 1)d6 of [spotted](/wiki/Spotted_jelly "Spotted jelly") and [blue jellies](/wiki/Blue_jellies "Blue jellies"), but being engulfed may force you to attack and risk corroding your weapon or armor (though the engulfing itself does *not* induce corrosion). A [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging") or [spell of dig](/wiki/Spell_of_dig "Spell of dig") will immediately free you from an ochre jelly and reduce its HP to 1.

For players keeping [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") [pets](/wiki/Pets "Pets") or [polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into one, each tentacle attack will trigger the passive; [acid resistance](/wiki/Acid_resistance "Acid resistance") via [yellow dragon scales](/wiki/Yellow_dragon_scales "Yellow dragon scales")/[scale mail](/wiki/Yellow_dragon_scale_mail "Yellow dragon scale mail") (or a spare [alchemy smock](/wiki/Alchemy_smock "Alchemy smock") for polymorphed players) will easily counteract this.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit 0891ef4](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/0891ef4e22ccb56bacd41ce302d4178c1c6525aa), monsters now gain acid resistance from a worn alchemy smock, allowing for more variety in equipping humanoid pets.

## History

The ochre jelly first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the ochre jelly's engulfing attack can corrode objects in open inventory, including your [alignment key](/wiki/Alignment_key "Alignment key").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the second alternate [Castle layout](/wiki/Castle_\(UnNetHack\) "Castle (UnNetHack)") has an ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") also makes use of the aforementioned Castle map, including the ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

## Encyclopedia entry

I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness. I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned. The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it.

\[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E. Czerneda ]

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Ochre jelly

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
j ochre jelly
Difficulty 8
Attacks Engulfs and covers with acidic slime 3d6, Passive 3d6 acid
j ochre jelly
Difficulty 8
Attacks

Engulfs and covers with acidic slime 3d6, Passive 3d6 acid

Base level 6
Base experience 88
Speed 3
Base AC 8
Base MR 20
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 50
Nutritional value 20
Size Medium
Resistances Acid, stoning
Resistances conveyed none

An ochre jelly:

  • can flow under doors.
  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • is acidic to eat.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
Reference monst.c#line518

An ochre jelly, j, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is an acidic amoeboid, and is the only non-sessile member of the jelly monster class.

Like other jellies the ochre jelly has a passive attack, which deals acid damage and can corrode iron or copper weapons and armor. It can also actively engulf a target to cover them with acidic slime.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 UnNetHack
    • 4.3 EvilHack
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Ochre jellies are the second quest monster encountered on the Knight quest branch, and have a 14% chance of being generated. Several ochre jellies are generated on the floors beyond the home level.

Ochre jellies may also be created by a hostile spellcaster casting the summon nasties monster spell.

Strategy

Ochre jellies are quite slow and can be easily outrun, allowing you to pick them off at a distance with corrode-proofed or disposable projectiles - you can also simply run away if you aren't prepared to handle them. Their passive acid attack does 3d6 damage as opposed to the (XL + 1)d6 of spotted and blue jellies, but being engulfed may force you to attack and risk corroding your weapon or armor (though the engulfing itself does not induce corrosion). A wand of digging or spell of dig will immediately free you from an ochre jelly and reduce its HP to 1.

For players keeping mind flayer pets or polymorphing into one, each tentacle attack will trigger the passive; acid resistance via yellow dragon scales/scale mail (or a spare alchemy smock for polymorphed players) will easily counteract this.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit 0891ef4, monsters now gain acid resistance from a worn alchemy smock, allowing for more variety in equipping humanoid pets.

History

The ochre jelly first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the ochre jelly's engulfing attack can corrode objects in open inventory, including your alignment key.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, the second alternate Castle layout has an ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

EvilHack

EvilHack also makes use of the aforementioned Castle map, including the ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

Encyclopedia entry

I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness. I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned. The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it.

[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E. Czerneda ]

An '''ochre jelly''', {{monsym|ochre jelly}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is an [[acidic]] [[amoeboid]], and is the only non-[[sessile]] member of the [[jelly]] [[monster class]].

Like other jellies the ochre jelly has a passive attack, which deals acid damage and can [[corrode]] [[iron]] or [[copper]] weapons and armor. It can also actively [[engulf]] a target to cover them with acidic slime.

==Generation==
Ochre jellies are the second quest monster encountered on the [[Knight quest]] branch, and have a 14% chance of being generated. Several ochre jellies are generated on the floors beyond the home level.

Ochre jellies may also be created by a hostile [[spellcaster]] casting the [[summon nasties]] [[monster spell]].

==Strategy==
Ochre jellies are quite slow and can be easily outrun, allowing you to pick them off at a distance with corrode-proofed or disposable projectiles - you can also simply run away if you aren't prepared to handle them. Their passive acid attack does 3d6 damage as opposed to the (XL + 1)d6 of [[spotted jelly|spotted]] and [[blue jellies]], but being engulfed may force you to attack and risk corroding your weapon or armor (though the engulfing itself does ''not'' induce corrosion). A [[wand of digging]] or [[spell of dig]] will immediately free you from an ochre jelly and reduce its HP to 1.

For players keeping [[mind flayer]] [[pets]] or [[polymorph]]ing into one, each tentacle attack will trigger the passive; [[acid resistance]] via [[yellow dragon scales]]/[[yellow dragon scale mail|scale mail]] (or a spare [[alchemy smock]] for polymorphed players) will easily counteract this.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Per {{commit|0891ef4e22ccb56bacd41ce302d4178c1c6525aa|commit 0891ef4}}, monsters now gain acid resistance from a worn alchemy smock, allowing for more variety in equipping humanoid pets.}}

==History==
The ochre jelly first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], the ochre jelly's engulfing attack can corrode objects in open inventory, including your [[alignment key]].

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], the second alternate [[Castle (UnNetHack)|Castle layout]] has an ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

===EvilHack===
[[EvilHack]] also makes use of the aforementioned Castle map, including the ochre jelly in the rightmost wing.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness.  I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned.  The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it.
|[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E. Czerneda ]
